title: Deliverance Through Judges
shortSummary: Judges Chapter 3 recounts the cycle of Israel’s disobedience, oppression by surrounding nations, crying out to God, and deliverance through judges raised by the Lord. It highlights God’s faithfulness in raising deliverers like Othniel and Ehud despite Israel’s repeated failures. This chapter sets the pattern of divine discipline and mercy that characterizes the book of Judges.
timeline: c. 1380-1300 BC - Early period of Israel's settlement in Canaan after Joshua's death

keyCharacters.name: Othniel
keyCharacters.description: The first judge raised by God to deliver Israel from Mesopotamian oppression; Caleb’s younger brother and a valiant warrior.

keyCharacters.name: Ehud
keyCharacters.description: A left-handed Benjamite judge who delivered Israel by assassinating Eglon, king of Moab, leading to Israel’s victory.

keyCharacters.name: Eglon
keyCharacters.description: The fat king of Moab who oppressed Israel for eighteen years until killed by Ehud.

keyCharacters.name: Shamgar
keyCharacters.description: A judge who delivered Israel by slaying six hundred Philistines with an ox goad.

definitions.definition: False gods worshiped by the Canaanites, representing fertility and storm deities, opposed to the LORD.

outline.heading: God’s Purpose in Leaving Nations
outline.description: God deliberately left certain nations in the land to test Israel’s faithfulness and teach them warfare, but Israel’s intermarriage with these peoples led to idolatry and disobedience.

outline.heading: Othniel’s Deliverance
outline.description: After Israel’s evil and subsequent oppression by Mesopotamia, God raises Othniel who, empowered by the Spirit of the LORD, delivers Israel and brings forty years of peace.

outline.heading: Oppression by Moab and Ehud’s Deliverance
outline.description: Israel again falls into evil, leading to Moabite oppression under King Eglon. Ehud, a left-handed judge, assassinates Eglon and leads Israel to a decisive victory, resulting in eighty years of peace.

outline.heading: Shamgar’s Brief Account
outline.description: A short mention of Shamgar who delivers Israel by killing six hundred Philistines with an ox goad, demonstrating God’s provision of deliverers in times of need.

application: Recognize that God allows trials to test and teach us, calling us to faithfulness and obedience.
Respond to oppression and hardship by crying out to the LORD for deliverance and trusting His timing.
Be willing to serve God boldly, like the judges, using the gifts and abilities He has given to overcome challenges.
Avoid compromising with worldly influences that lead to idolatry and spiritual decline.

keyVerses.text: And when the children of Israel cried unto the LORD, the LORD raised up a deliverer to the children of Israel, who delivered them, even Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s mercy and faithfulness in raising deliverers when His people repent and cry out.

keyVerses.text: And Ehud came unto him; and he was sitting in a summer parlour, which he had for himself alone. And Ehud said, I have a message from God unto thee. And he arose out of his seat.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces Ehud’s bold and strategic approach to deliverance, showing God’s use of unexpected means to save His people.

keyVerses.text: So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest fourscore years.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the peace and blessing that follow deliverance when Israel is faithful to God.
